clinical_study.brief_title: Hyperpolarized Noble Gas MR Imaging for Pulmonary Disorders
clinical_study.official_title: Hyperpolarized Noble Gas MR Imaging for Pulmonary Disorders

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test the efficacy of Hyperpolarized Helium-3 gas in MR imaging in COPD, asthmatics, CF and healthy volunteers.

detailed_description.textblock: Current pulmonary imaging techniques are clinically regulated to machines that produce radiation. MR which does not produce radiation was not possible due to the low concentration of fluids in the open spaces of the lungs. With hyperpolarized noble gases we can now use the safe techniques of MR imaging to view the airways of the lungs, thus limiting human exposure to radiation. This technique has already been proven to be possible in human subjects but there is insufficient data show its efficacy in a clinical setting. This study is designed to image a variety of pulmonary disorders to better find possible clinical uses for hyperpolarized gas MRI.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The study was halted prematurely as the PI was no longer an employee of UMass Medical School.

primary_outcome.description: We have applied hyperpolarized 3He MR imaging to a range of subject with various disorders. We have developed our scanning techniques so as to acquire optimized images for each disorder.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Are male or female and are 5 years or older
- Consent/assent from the patient
- Have been diagnosed with a pulmonary disease such as COPD, Asthma, or cystic fibrosis. OR Healthy Individuals.
- Must be able to hold their breath for up to 15 seconds
Exclusion Criteria:
- Have any contraindications to an MR exam such as a pace-maker, metallic cardiac valves, magnetic material (i.e., surgical clips) implanted electronic infusion pumps or any other conditions that would preclude proximity to a strong magnetic field;
- Are undergoing the MR exam in an emergency situation
- Are pregnant or become pregnant at any point within the study time.
- People with psychiatric disorders will be excluded from the study.
- Are claustrophobic and can not tolerate the imaging.
- Uses supplemental oxygen

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment began November 2008 and enrollment started January 2009. Recruitment continued until the study was terminated, April 2011. Participants were asthmatics, COPD patients, or CF patients as confirmed by their physician. Recruitment was completed from the UMass Memorial Medical Centre. Alternatively, healthy volunteers were also recruited.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were excluded if their diagnosis of a lung condition could not be confirmed by medical records.
